ygData.msgSnippet: Another approach is to have channel IDs. It depends on the activation function, but when a link is added/removed, the node will reassign all links to the

Subject: Re: ANJI : NEAT implementation (fingerprint implementation issues)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=LqKz7BuJHygmNdaSSX0V7nm4F3lb5D1CO4TJ_v6SuPQR-DQAsuw7Cln0kQ

Another approach is to have channel IDs. It depends on the activation 
func=
tion, but when a link is added/removed, the node will reassign 
all links t=
o the channel IDs. Let me show you what I mean. We have 
this node, with 3 =
connections incoming and 2 outgoing.
The activation function is (u,v) =3D f=
(x,y) type. Given the activation 
function, we can reassign the links like =
that:

incoming[0]->link
incoming_channel[0] =3D=3D 0
incoming[1]->link
inc=
oming_channel[1] =3D=3D 0
incoming[2]->link
incoming_channel[2] =3D=3D 1

o=
utgoing[0]->link
outgoing_channel[0] =3D=3D 0
outgoing[1]->link
outgoing_ch=
annel[1] =3D=3D 1

The summation is done on per channel basis. Then the res=
ults from the 
incoming channels are fed in the (x, y) and the results from=
 the 
activation function are fed in the outgoing channels (0 and 1) - (u 
=
and v). 

To demonstrate the flexibility of this method, let me show what 
=
happens when we add an incoming connection. The node will have a 
reassign_=
channels() method:

incoming[0]->link
incoming_channel[0] =3D=3D 0
incoming=
[1]->link
incoming_channel[1] =3D=3D 0
incoming[2]->link
incoming_channel[2=
] =3D=3D 1
incoming[3]->link
incoming_channel[3] =3D=3D 1

Now suppose we h=
ave a mutation that changes the activation function 
to a y=3Df(x) type. re=
assign_channels() takes this into account and we 
end up with:

incoming[0]=
->link
incoming_channel[0] =3D=3D 0
incoming[1]->link
incoming_channel[1] =
=3D=3D 0
incoming[2]->link
incoming_channel[2] =3D=3D 0
incoming[3]->link
i=
ncoming_channel[3] =3D=3D 0

outgoing[0]->link
outgoing_channel[0] =3D=3D 0=

outgoing[1]->link
outgoing_channel[1] =3D=3D 0

- all in the same channel.=


Which approach is better, I don't know. :)

Peter

> wrote:
> > > > >
> =
> > > > Here are my thoughts after reading through this very 
> > interesti=
ng 
> > > > > conversation.
> > > > > 
> > > > > First, I agree rotation is=
 an important issue for 
HyperNEAT; 
> > > > however, 
> > > > > I am confi=
dent that is can be dealt with.  It's an 
> interesting 
> > > open 
> > > =
> > research problem.
> > > > > 
> > > > > In any case, there is an importa=
nt aspect of this issue 
that 
> we 
> > > > > should also be considering. =
 The problem is not simply to 
be 
> > able 
> > > > to 
> > > > > perform =
a rotation. As Jason's posts imply (and Peter 
> stated), 
> > > > > HyperN=
EAT and CPPNs should technically already be able to 
> > perform 
> > > > >=
 rotations.  And, in fact, they do.  When I play with God 
Mode 
> > in 
> =
> > > > genetic art I often find weights that when adjusted rotate 
a 
> > =
part 
> > > > of 
> > > > > the image.  That is not that unusual (although =
perhaps not 
as 
> > > usual 
> > > > > as we'd like either).
> > > > > 
> =
> > > > However, that kind of rotation actually *isn't* the type we 
> > > =
really 
> > > > > need.  The issue is not that a particular shape should be=
 
> > > possible 
> > > > to 
> > > > > rotate some arbitrary angle by chan=
ging some weights. 
Recall 
> > that 
> > > > > CPPNs work by laying out co=
ordinate frames within which 
> higher 
> > > > > strucutres are situated. =
 To create a symmetric coordinate 
> > frame 
> > > > means
> > > > > creat=
ing a gradient with *two* sides, both the opposite of 
> each 
> > > > > ot=
her.  That is, symmetry is not created by flipping a 
> gradient 
> > > > f=
rom 
> > > > > one side to the other, but rather by having both sides at 
t=
he 
> > > same 
> > > > > time.
> > > > > 
> > > > > Therefore, a rotationa=
l coordinate frame should actually 
> > contain 
> > > > > something akin t=
o a sinusoidal gradient that spreads around 
a 
> > > > circle 
> > > > > r=
ather than along a line. Then, structures situated within 
> its 
> > > > >=
 coordinate frame would repeat in a rotated regular pattern, 
> > like 
> >=
 > > > petals on a flower (that way you get rotatonal 
invariance).  
> > >=
 > > 
> > > > > Thus what we really want is to be able to feed in a regular=
 
> 2D 
> > > > > coordinate frame and output another coordinate frame that=
 
is 
> a 
> > > sine 
> > > > > wave around a circle in 2D as well.  In ot=
her words:
> > > > > 
> > > > > f(x,y)=3Da point in this circular petal-lik=
e gradient
> > > > > 
> > > > > Thus we only need to define a function like=
 that and make 
it 
> an 
> > > > > activation function that takes two dist=
inct inputs.
> > > > > 
> > > > > However, the problem does remain of where=
 to control the 
> period 
> > > of 
> > > > > repetition around the circle=
.
> > > > > 
> > > > > Actually, thinking of it now, what we really want is=
 NOT 
what 
> I 
> > > > just 
> > > > > said but rather something a bit di=
fferent that would solve 
> the 
> > > > > problem I just posed: What we wa=
nt is a function f(x,y) 
that 
> > > > produces 
> > > > > a gradient that =
starts at 0 on e.g. the x axis and then 
> > increases 
> > > > up 
> > > >=
 > to 1 as you rotate around the origin to 360 degrees.
> > > > > 
> > > > =
> That way, you have a true circular/polar coordinate 
system.  
> > Then 
=
> > > > you 
> > > > > can simply run its output into a sine wave, and you =
get the 
> > > > > repetition around the circle that I describe above.  The=
n 
the 
> > > > > frequency of repetition is controlled very easily by 
var=
ying 
> > the 
> > > > > weight leaving the polar function and entering the=
 sine 
wave, 
> > > just 
> > > > > as in any normal CPPN!
> > > > > 
> > >=
 > > So I guess my conclusion is we just need a function that 
> > converts=
 
> > > > > Cartesian coordinates to a polar angle, and then running 
its 
=
> > > output 
> > > > > into a periodic activation function will give your =
nice 
> > > rotational 
> > > > > repetition, which in a neural substrate i=
s rotational 
> > invariance!
> > > > > 
> > > > > Hmm...so I think this ex=
plains in part how to deal with the 
> > > issue, 
> > > > > though maybe n=
ot 100% (it doesn't explain what it means if 
> the 
> > > > inputs 
> > > =
> > to such a polar conversion function are not the base-level 
x 
> > and =

> > > y, 
> > > > > but I think such cases will actually yield nice locali=
zed 
> > > > rotational 
> > > > > effects as well).  
> > > > > 
> > > > >=
 Sorry for writing out my thoughts as they come to me in 
> stream 
> > of =

> > > > > consciousness- this is a rare case where I'm thinking of 
> idea=
s 
> > as 
> > > I 
> > > > > write!
